summary: The study was published in the journal CPLC journal J.C.Creprep.org . The study is published on the CPLP journal Creprep .

The central nervous system (CNS) is particularly vulnerable to space stressors . Studies have reported behavioral deficits in spatial orientation, coordination, and locomotion . There is still insufficient data regarding its long-term health risks .

The flies were reared either under a 1g force in space or in.  and radiation environments in space . Upon completing the mission, a postflight ground control experiment was performed on Earth (Earth) using the same flight hardware and simulating spaceflight conditions . The flies retrieved upon completion of the mission were used for behavioral, morphological, and acclimation analyses to study the

Camera represents inflight videos that were recorded to monitor fly health and behavior . Onboard operations included freezing the food cylinders containing flies and larvae in RNAlater for omics analysis . Live flies were returned to Earth . A subset of F1 flies used for behavioral assays to measure climbing ability .

Climbing ability is the fly’s innate negative geotactic response and is routinely used to assess nervous system dysfunction in fly models . We observed that males born in μg were more affected with significant deficits in climbing ability compared to Earth males . A decreasing trend was also observed in SFμg females and SF1g (males and females) compared to their respective Earth control .  Neuropil area is significantly reduced in SFμg flies compared to Earth and SF1g control flies in both sexes . A similar phenotype was noted in the Alzheimer’s disease fly model accompanied with behavioral deficits .
The radiation environment in LEO is known to be more benign than the environment in deep space, beyond the Van Allen belts (Nelson

The gross physiological changes induced in LEO flights like on ISS, as observed in SFμg flies, at least for the CNS immediately post-return, may primarily be associated with changes in gravity . These results indicate that gravity can play a key role in the LEO environment, causing neuronal and neurobehavioral deficits during spaceflight .

Table provides a global view of the total number of differentially up and down regulated genes (DEGs) and proteins (DEPs) in SF1g and SFμg compared to Earth control . Proteomic data of SF μg flies (males and females) show enrichment of pathways such as endocytosis, cellular metabolic responsive pathways – tyrosine metabolism,
Spaceflight alters the expression of stress-inducible proteins affecting CNS . The stress response under spaceflight conditions (SFμg> SF1g) suggests high energy demand .
The number of proteins altered is higher in SFμg condition than SF1g . Males show more changes than females . Prostitutes associated with muscle and cytoskeleton are also noted in spaceflight flies .
Repo positive cells at R+25 days showed total glial loss (D) and increase in the aggregates/rosettes (F) in SFμg, SF1g .
Spaceflight effects on the brain at the molecular, morphological, and behavioral levels.  insights into spaceflight effects .

There is a gap in our understanding of AG prescriptions required to ameliorate the health concerns during spaceflight . We utilized MVP hardware featuring an inflight centrifuge that simulates Earth’s gravity on the ISS (SF1g) to address this knowledge gap . The inflight video recording capability aided in assessing the health of the flies during the mission .

We hypothesize that the observed alterations in the metabolic pathways are an effort to restore cellular homeostasis . Microgravity in SFμg acts as an additional stressor, potentially resulting in elevated oxidative stress .

Radiation studies in ground-based rodent models indicate that exposure to deep space radiation can affect behavior . These phenotypes in SF1g at R+25 may be a delayed response to radiation combined with exposure to other space stressors such as elevated CO <sub>2</sub>.

In an enclosed and isolated environment of the ISS, astronauts experience elevated CO<sub>2</sub> levels that are considerably higher than ambient levels on Earth . In our study, the Earth control flies were exposed to an environment mimicking ISS and experienced high CO <sub>.sub>levels similar to SF1g and SFμg flies, in contrast to regular lab conditions .
The mission used the MVP hardware (Redwire/Techshot, Inc., Greenville, Indiana) that supports easy food changes, allowing for a

The housing system consists of two independent centrifuge units maintained within the same habitat enclosure, each containing six MVP modules . Each MVP module has two adult fly chambers and three food cylinders . Each food cylinder holds approximately 9.2 mL of standard fly food containing foodgrade blue food dye . The video was periodically checked during the mission to ensure the health of flies and gauge the overall well-being

A ground-based ground control with the same hardware used for the mission was conducted in a ground incubator with six MVP modules resulting in 883 flies . For the postflight control (Earth), flies were placed in each module to match the flight condition and were reared under identical conditions . Food cylinder 1 from each module containing F2 generation fruit fly eggs and larvae, and some F1 generation adults, was fixed in RNAlater (Invitrogen) Food cylinder 3 was reopened to adult fly chamber 2 to continue providing food to this population for the remainder of the experiment . Food cylinder 2 remained open to chamber 1 during egg lay to allow adults to continue emerging .

Full resolution 8-bit images (1986x1064) were used for analysis . Individual frames from the video images have a predominant intensity in the blue channel . Each video image was separated into its three RGB components, and each video was inverted . The resulting images had individual flies that appeared as white pixels on a gray background . Climbing assay was performed on F1 generation of flies returned to Earth using a modified version of Le Bourg and Lints . The experiment was launched with flies in chamber 2/cylinder 3 and food in cylinder 3 . Food cylinders 2 and 1 were not included in launch orientation .

The MVP unit was powered on, and fruit fly food cylinder 2 was retrieved from 4°C storage and inserted into the module . The launch configuration allowed each module to have a food cylinder in the “food cylinder 3” slot, to support the first generation of flies during launch .
